name: ctenium-aromaticum
country-or-region-of-origin: Southeastern Coastal Plain of the United States
wildlife-value: Provides cover for birds, reptiles, and small mammals. Host plant for skippers. Seeds are eaten by birds. Foliage may be browsed by ruminants but is not preferred.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Fruit is an awned grain. After dropping the fruit, the seed heads curl into a spiral or corkscrew shape.
flower-description: Inflorescence is a panicle with awned spikelets on one side of the rachis, giving the appearance of a fine-tooth comb. Second glume of each spikelet with two conspicuous rows of glands. Blooms in mid- to late summer but may bloom in early autumn following a burn.
leaf-description: Leaves bicolored and rather broad, bright bluish-green on the upper surface and pale green on the lower surface. Stem leaves shorter than basal leaves. Old sheaths form fibrous mat at the base of the clump.
uses: Has been used as a sialagogue, an agent that increases saliva. Perhaps used historically as a toothache remedy.
